title.narrative: Peace Building and Community Cohesion Project, Fas 2
Peace Building and Community Cohesion Project, Phase 2

description.narrative:
Sida har stött UNDP och dess arbete för fred och sammanhållning på lokalsamhällesnivå i Sudsudan sedan 2014, i projektet Commuity Security and Arms Control 2014-2016 (40 MSEK) följt av fas 1 av Peace and Community Cohesion, 2017-2020 (60 MSEK). Ett projektförslag för PaCC fas 2 inkom till Sida 12 februari 2020. Förutom projektdokumentet har beredningen av insatsen grundats på den externa utvärderingen av fas 1 och de årliga resultatrapporterna från fas 1.
PaCC II bygger på de tidigare två projekten. De tre projekten formar sammantaget en långsiktig strävan av UNDP att skapa en gynnsam miljö för genomförandet av det nu gällande fredsavtalet mellan regering och väpnad opposition - the Revitalised Agreement on the Resolution of Conflict in the Republic of South Sudan, R-ARCSS - och tidigare fredsavtal. Det nya projektet kommer att både fördjupa och utvidga redan pågående initiativ för att bygga fred och sammanhållning från gräsrotsnivå och uppåt till central nivå i samhället. Pågående verksamhet under PaCC I kommer att fördjupas i de fem geografiska konfliktområden (conflict clusters) där UNDP redan arbetar och också utvidgas till två ytterligare konfliktområden.
Projektets övergripande mål (outcome) är att, i enlighet med UNDP:s landprogram för Sydsudan, Sydsudans befolkning och då i synnerhet de mest sårbara grupperna kan dra nytta av vad UNDP benämner en stärkt infrastruktur för fred, ökad sammanhållning, försoning och tillit samt stärkt ansvarsutkrävande på alla nivåer. Målet kommer att nås via tre resultat: 1. Infrastrukturen för fred (institutioner, lagstiftining, personal etc) på lokal och central nivå är formade så att de har förmågan att hantera konflikter och främja fredlig samexistens; 2. Lokalsamhällena har fungerande strukturer som uppmuntrar och främjar traumabearbetning, försoning och våldsreducering och som stärker social sammanhållning; 3. Fredsprocesser har ett integrerat jämställdhetsperspektiv och förutsättningarna för kvinnors, ungas och minoriteters deltagande i beslutsfattande har stärkts.
De huvudsakliga målgrupperna för insatsen är unga, kvinnor och flickor, människor med funktionsnedsättning samt minoritetsgrupper i sju olika geografiska konfliktområden kring Bor, Wau, Aweil, Bentiu, Malakal, Torit och Rumbek. Beteenden och värderingar i lokalsamhällena kommer att ändras genom stärkande av dessa gruppers deltgande i beslutsfattande och andra viktiga samhällsprocesser .
PaCC II är ett brett, omfattande projekt som syftar till att stärka sambanden mellan det humanitära biståndet, utvecklings- och fredsarbetet, dvs det som benämns trippel-nexus. Projektet innehåller stöd till såväl konfliktförebyggande, medling och annat fredsskapande som tidig återuppbyggnad, i syfte att minska risken för våldsam konflikt och kriser, vilka skapar behov av humanitär hjälp och undergräver utveckling.
Det fyraåriga projektets totala budget är 35 MUSD, motsvarande cirka 315 MSEK. Det föreslagna bidraget från Sida är 120 MSEK över de fyra åren, från juni 2020 till mars 2024. Det utgör cirka 33% av den totala budgeten. Andra biståndsgivare är Japan, KOICA (Sydkorea) och Afrikanska utvecklingsbanken.

Sida has been supporting UNDP and its work for peace and community cohesion in South Sudan since 2014, in the Community Security and Arms Control project 2014-2016 (40 MSEK) followed by the Peace and Community Cohesion project (PaCC) 2017-2020 (60 MSEK). A proposal for PaCC Phase II was submitted to Sida on 12 February 2020. In addition to the Project Document, the appraisal was based on an external evaluation of PaCC Phase I, dated January 2020, and narrative and financial reports of Phase I.
PaCC II is built on the previous two projects. The three projects taken together form a long term effort of UNDP to promoting a conducive environment for successful implementation of the Revitalised Agreement on the Resolution of Conflict in the Republic of South Sudan, R-ARCSS, and previous peace agreements. The new project will deepen and expand on ongoing initiatives to build peace and cohesion from the grassroots to the national level. Ongoing activities under PaCC I will be deepened in the currently targeted conflict clusters (geographical areas), and be expanded to at least two more conflict clusters.
The overarching objective (outcome) of the project, aligned with the UNDP South Sudan Country Programme Document, is that the South Sudanese population, particularly the most vulnerable groups, benefit from strengthened peace infrastructures, increased cohesion, reconciliation, trust and accountable governance at all levels. This goal will be reached through achievement of three outputs:
1. Infrastructures of peace at the central and local levels are enabled to manage conflicts and foster peaceful co-existence;
2. Communities have structures to encourage trauma healing, reconciliation, violence reduction and reinforce social cohesion;
3. Peace processes are engendered and conditions of women, youth and minority participation in decision making improved.
The main target groups are youth, women, persons with disability and minority groups in seven so called conflict clusters around Bor, Wau, Aweil, Bentiu, Malakal, Torit and Rumbek. Behaviour and attitudes at communal level will be changed through strengthening of capacity and increased participation of these groups in decision making and other key processes.
PaCC II is a broad, comprehensive project that aims at strengthening the coherence between humanitarian, development and peace efforts, i.e. the triple nexus. The project includes support for prevention, mediation and peacebuilding and early recovery, with a view to decreasing the risk of violent conflict and crises that generate humanitarian needs and undermine development.
The total budget of the four-year project is 35 MUSD, or approximately 315 MSEK. The proposed contribution from Sida is 120 MSEK over the four year period, from June 2020 to March 2024. It constitutes about 33 % of the total budget. Other contributing donors are Japan, KOICA (South Korea) and the African Development Bank.

title.narrative: Financing Agreement between Sweden, represented by Sida, and UNDP on the Peace and Community Cohesion Project in South Sudan, Phase II
Beslut om ändring av insats PaCC II
Decision on contribution Peace and Community Cohesion Project in South Sudan, phase II

description.narrative: PaCC II has rolled out smoothly and the overall progress towards project output is good. Examples of results achieved within the PaCC II project during the first half year of operation, June to November 2020, includes: - The establishment of 14 Payam and one county level Peace Committees; 219 (whereof 31 percent women) Peace Committee members are trained in Transformational Leadership, Conflict Management and GBV. - 107 cases of SGBV were resolved by community psychosocial support groups; cases were taken to court, and the survivors were given psychosocial concelling and other medical services. Tension created between the clans of the perpetrators and the survivors were in many cases solved through mediation. - Enhanced capacity of 133 women leaders for effective participation in local governance and peace processes (in Aweil, Wau, Bentiu and Juba). - A study on youth subculture was completed, guiding the further engagement of youths within the PaCC project. - Support to High Level committee for investigating the conflict in Jonglei and Pibor (including a field mission to Pibor). The focus on UNSCR 1325 during the course of PaCC II, as well as during the former phase of PaCC, has resulted in increased participation in peace and governance processes of women leaders and young women aspiring to become leaders. During the activity period for PaCC II, young aspiring women leaders have mobilized 70 youth to volunteer in a door-to-door Covid-19 prevention campaign. As a result, the young women have formed the first-ever youth volunteer movement in South Sudan. Based on results from the previous phase, PaCC I, it can be seen that the projects have had a positive impact on cattle related conflicts, which are now more often successfully avoided or de-escalated through the traditional conflict resolution mechanism under the auspices of UNDP's civil society partners. The social economic activities for women, organised within the project, improved both inter-communal relations and the livelihood of the participating women. Furthermore, through coaching and mentorship, youth and persons with disability improved their skills, permitting them to gain greater confidence for participation in peace and governance processes. Although progress towards the objectives are overall good, the Covid-19 pandemic and subsequent restrictions on movement have hampered the ability to successfully achieve all set goals for 2020. The deteriorating security situation in some of the targeted areas are further delaying the implementation of activities. In addition, excessive flooding during 2020 delayed the finalisation of some of the activities pertaining to infrastructure. UNDP identifies a number of lessons learned, including the importance of engaging youth and the use community radios to promote peace, prevent Covid-19 and countering hate. Furthermore, UNDP identifies the use of arts and sports as an efficient method for strengthening the social cohesion among youth. During 2021, UNDP envisages that the project will strengthen efforts to reduce community and small arms violence, re-integrate ex-combatants as well as dealing with other underlying causes for conflict such as cattle raiding. Youth, peace and security will be another area of focus.
